title: Cell to Cell Signaling in Immune Response

content.description: An antigen can induce an immune response in a host organism. Antigens are targeted by antibodies that are produced by the organismâ€™s immune system in response to contact with the antigen. Antibodies are specific to antigens. Many different cell types are involved in immune responses.
content.question: Which of the following best explains the role of cell-to-cell communication during a response to an invasion of antigens?

choices.label: Chemicals that are secreted from antigen-presenting cells then activate helper T cells.
A macrophage cell engulfs a pathogen in the blood.
Antigens attaching to receptors on memory B cells stimulate the memory B cells to become plasma cells.
Antigen-presenting cells engulf antigens at the first exposure.

content.answer: Chemicals that are secreted from antigen-presenting cells then activate helper T cells.
